subject: Re: [junit] a test framework to codify levelizaton?
msgSnippet: ... Data point from over here: Running the Jena test suite in Eclipse takes approx 50 seconds on my 2Gb 3GHz machine. (Hmm, missing some stuff there - must
messageBody:
On Saturday 17 July 2004 05:03, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Vlad Roubtsov wrote:
> > On any but the trivial projects the number of
> > testcases quickly exceeds 100-200+. It usually takes a
> > noticeable time to run them all.
>
> Can you quantify this? GSBase, for example, runs tests at approximately
> 100/second, and that's my usual performance goal for tests. On my most
> recent project, I separated tests that required expensive, external
> resources (there were about 10) from tests than ran entirely in memory
> (there were about 400). The in-memory tests ran in about 6 seconds.
>
> Is this "noticeable" by your standards? I'd merely like some extra context.

Data point from over here:

Running the Jena test suite in Eclipse takes approx 50 seconds on my 2Gb
3GHz machine. (Hmm, missing some stuff there - must sort out the
proxy settings). More like 40s outside Eclipse (and with a working proxy).

I used to run with a 0.8GHz supposedly-dula processor and we were talking
more like 120s. (The database tests are separate and take 60s seconds
to run, for mySQL on Linux at least - at one point it was more like 20minutes,
argh scream; I suspect there aren't enough of them.)

The test suite is rather a hotchpotch, as it contains ancient tests from
before our more systematic use of JUnit which are more like acceptance
tests than unit tests, but them's what we have. Usually I run the tests for
the bit I'm tinkering with at a moments provocation and run the full suite
when I reach some kind of anchor point - the necessity for loading or
unloading tea, the final new feature working, or Oh My Stars Has It Been
An Hour?!

--
Chris "Jena RDF HP" Dollin
